p: Most notably hailed as a marvel of convenience in the 1950s (e.g. Life 1955), plastic is now perhaps better known for its polluting capabilities and its ubiquity as a form of ever-fragmenting waste. Its abundance and durability, which have made it a wonderfully cheap and reliable construction material for humans, have also endowed it with a lasting presence in ecosystems all around the world; some plastic has already occupied natural environments for decades beyond its original, typically fleeting, use (Lebreton et al. 2018). The long-term environmental impacts of plastic are claimed to be, at best, “unknown” and “irreversible” (Hohn et al. 2020), while other predictions are much more sobering: that plastic fragmentation is the beginning of a delayed, cumulative release of toxic chemicals, a “global plastic toxicity debt” (Rillig et al. 2021); and that plastic is “poised to dominate the 21st century as one of the yet-unchecked drivers of climate change” (Altman 2022).
